title: 109_s2347
content: Extension and modification of treatment of qualified zone academy bonds. Extension and Allocation of Credit Authority: The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to extend the national zone academy bond limitations for calendar years 2005, 2006, and 2007. The allocation of limitation among states is based on their respective populations below the poverty line. The national zone academy bond limitation after 2005 is allocated among states based on the amounts each state received for basic grants under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The national zone academy bond limitation is allocated among states based on the amounts received for basic grants under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. Each state's allocation must not be less than 1 percent of the total limitation, and the state then allocates this amount to qualified zone academies within its borders. The maximum face amount of bonds issued annually for a qualified zone academy is limited to the allocation amount. Unused bond allocation can be reallocated after two years. Rules similar to section 42(h)(3)(D) apply for this section. Proceeds of bonds can now be used for constructing, rehabilitating, or repairing facilities. The limitation on taxpayers eligible for credit is repealed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow the tax credit for qualified zone academy bonds to be claimed by shareholders of regulated investment companies. Additionally, regulations may allow for the separation of ownership of these bonds. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code allow the tax credit for qualified zone academy bonds to be claimed by shareholders of regulated investment companies. Ownership of the bond and entitlement to the credit can be separated, with specific rules applying. These changes apply to obligations issued after December 31, 2005. The limitation on zone academy bond holders under section 1397E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is repealed for bonds issued after December 31, 2005.
